# _Judge Mathis_

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

This article is about the television series. For the eponymous arbiter of this
court show, see [Greg Mathis](/wiki/Greg_Mathis "Greg Mathis").

_**Judge Mathis**_ is a syndicated [arbitration-based
reality](/wiki/Court_show#Arbitration-based_reality_court_show "Court show")
[court show](/wiki/Court_show "Court show") presided over by the retired
[Judge](/wiki/Judge "Judge") of [Michigan](/wiki/Michigan "Michigan")'s 36th
[District Court](/wiki/Michigan_district_courts "Michigan district courts"),
[Greg Mathis](/wiki/Greg_Mathis "Greg Mathis").[1] The
[syndicated](/wiki/Broadcast_syndication "Broadcast syndication") series
features Mathis adjudicating [small claims](/wiki/Small_claims "Small claims")
disputes.

The series was originally produced by Black Pearl Entertainment. It's now
produced by [Telepictures Productions](/wiki/Telepictures_Productions
"Telepictures Productions") and Syndicated Productions, while distributed by
[Warner Bros. Television](/wiki/Warner_Bros._Television "Warner Bros.
Television").[2] It is taped at the [NBC Tower](/wiki/NBC_Tower "NBC Tower")
in [Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago"), but includes cases and
[litigants](/wiki/Litigants "Litigants") from other U.S. jurisdictions.

Greg Mathis's "inspirational and positive messages to young people" won the
court show a PRISM Commendation in May 2002. The court show also won an
_[NAACP Image Award](/wiki/NAACP_Image_Award "NAACP Image Award")_ in 2004 and
a Daytime Emmy Award in 2018.[1]

Each _Judge Mathis_ episode runs for one hour and typically consists of 4
cases.[1] The show is broadcast weekdays nationwide in the United States. It
is also broadcast in Canada through [Omni Television](/wiki/Omni_Television
"Omni Television").[3][4] The show has aired since 1999 and has aired over
2000 episodes.

In the 2014-15 television season, _Judge Mathis_ began its 16th season, making
Mathis the longest serving [African American](/wiki/African_American "African
American") court show arbitrator, after [Judge Joe
Brown](/wiki/Joe_Brown_\(judge\) "Joe Brown \(judge\)") whose
[program](/wiki/Judge_Joe_Brown "Judge Joe Brown") lasted 15 seasons.

_Judge Mathis_ is the fourth longest running courtroom series behind _[Divorce
Court](/wiki/Divorce_Court "Divorce Court")_ , _[The People's
Court](/wiki/The_People%27s_Court "The People's Court")_, and _Judge Judy_. It
began its 19th season on Monday, September 4, 2017.[5]

## Show format[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Judge_Mathis&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Show format")]

The cases on _Judge Mathis_ are classified as [tort law](/wiki/Tort_law "Tort
law"), civil disputes with a maximum $5,000 claim, a typical amount for [small
claims court](/wiki/Small_claims_court "Small claims court"). The producers of
the show select the cases. To acquire cases, the show solicits real-life
[litigants](/wiki/Litigant "Litigant") with pending disputes or individuals
with potential disputes. If litigants agree to be on the show, they are paid a
talent fee ranging from $150 to $300, and they receive travel accommodations.
Mathis does have prior knowledge of the cases. In all cases, litigants give
their prospective case managers all evidence in advance. Any real legal case
pending must be dismissed by both parties. Typically, Mathis's producers only
seek cases that they deem "juicy" enough for TV. Occasionally, Mathis leaves
the courtroom to deliberate and then returns with his verdict.[6] Upon final
judgment, he may briefly explain the legal principle guiding his verdict,
especially if his ruling is based on a particular state's law. Reportedly,
Mathis' rulings conform to the laws of the state where the case was originally
filed.[7]

## Incorporation of life story into court
show[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Judge_Mathis&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Incorporation of life story into court show")]

As a child and a teenager, Mathis was frequently in legal trouble. He was a
member of a street gang in Detroit, and he was arrested and sentenced to jail
for illegally carrying a firearm when he was 17 years old.[8]

Mathis has frequently used his courtroom series to highlight his troubled-
youth-turned-success-story as a way of motivating and inspiring his audience
(especially youth audience) that there's no adversity that they can't pick
themselves up from. It is from his background where Mathis derives much of his
courtroom formula. For example, his show's opening theme was formerly a brief
documentary of his powerful life story. As another example, he takes a liking
to litigants who've seen the error of their ways and have made efforts to
improve and better their lives.[9]

## Judge Gregory Mathis's adjudicating
approach[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Judge_Mathis&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Judge Gregory Mathis's adjudicating approach")]

Main article: [Greg Mathis](/wiki/Greg_Mathis "Greg Mathis")

Mathis typically begins proceedings by having [litigants](/wiki/Litigant
"Litigant") expound on their side of the dispute, so as to gain insight into
the matter. Cases on _Judge Mathis_ tend to go deeper and to more revealing
places than those of most other court shows. He also calls attention to
peculiarities or juicy details exposed throughout the course of the
proceedings as a means of making the cases more interesting to viewers.
Furthermore, Mathis doesn't hesitate to tackle any social issues that emerge
during the proceedings, tying his [social justice](/wiki/Social_justice
"Social justice") perspectives to the cases.[9]

While hearing the testimonies, Mathis takes on a relaxed, attentive,
understanding and open-minded nature. Rarely missing an opportunity to jest or
poke fun, Mathis is given to fun, humor, good-natured ridicule and gibes,
often rousing his audience to uproarious amusement. He sometimes cuts the
tension–even tension he himself has fostered–with wisecracks or taunting
remarks. Mathis has bantered directly at audience members on occasion, also
resulting in audience amusement.[10] He uses a rather high-pitched voice as
part of stultifying litigants and suggesting that they've not recognized the
obvious.[9][11]

Combined with his teasing and comedic tendencies on the bench,[10] Mathis is
known for his [street smart](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/street-smart
"wikt:street-smart"), urban expressions and stern side as well. In moments in
which Mathis has found a litigant guilty of a particularly reprehensible act,
he takes on a very [resentful](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/resent
"wikt:resent") nature along with lecturing and shaming behaviors. Sometimes in
these moments, Mathis makes a point of solemnizing his courtroom due to prior
laughs and lightheartedness, letting litigants and everyone on hand know that
things are no longer a laughing matter and that he's to be taken seriously.

The final portion of most of the cases generally see Mathis displaying a
harshly corrective side, providing an explanation behind the direction of his
[verdict](/wiki/Verdict "Verdict") in the form of a sharp tirade, unbroken in
delivery so as not to allow anyone a word in edgewise before his gavel pound
and exit.
